comments.commentBody: For all the comparisons to Hitler (extreme) and Mussolini (probably closer), all I can think of is that this clown really reminds me of Senator Palpatine, Sith Lord Darth Sidious.  "This is how liberty dies....to thunderous applause", right.  And speaking of clowns, Pagliacci also comes to mind.  I needed the chuckle but, sadly, this man represents a very real problem for all of us.  We should be paying close attention to what the world is saying.
And you can count Justin Trudeau of Canada among those profoundly concerned about the impact on the western alliance of a President Trump.

Unbelievable. Mr Friedman is actually predicting the behavior of the most unpredictable presidential candidate in modern American history. No qualifiers in this opinion. If nothing else Mr. Trump is an engaging, spontaneous, jocular speaker without peer in this election. Balancing the books the Bern is quite engaging as well. What a fascinating campaign whatever the outcome!

Our aging liberals on the Ed Board think any American would give two cents for what a Latin American leader says about our candidates, or about ANYTHING? You old people REALLY need to get out more.

The only thing about Mexico that we should adopt is their stringent border enforcement. The failed states to our south are the ones bleeding people, so no one else will ever see those societies as offering us good examples.

What the Editorial Board really wants to say is, ''Why doesn't everyone else hate the people WE hate?'' You hermits are SO quaint that it's kind of cute.

There, there. Here's a head pat. Now sit down and listen.

Every time Donald Trump wins another primary, I shake my head.  Who are these Trump-eters and can't they see that the man they admire is full of bluster and bigotry, but with no substance?  Can't they see that his plans to "make America great again" are nothing more than empty words with no connection to reality?  Even if Trump doesn't become president, his legacy of stupidity will continue on, allowing others to step up the podium of arrogance and ignorance.

They are grasping, and choose straw over hot air.
The manufacturing base of the US is in worse shape than it would be had we lost WWII, the 99% are fighting in the streets for the meagre crumbs dropped by the idle rich, and the infrastructure is that of Romania.
It was the Republicans who obstructed, but it was Obama who packed his staff with banksters.
Sorry, but they won't be fooled again.

This is an important message, one that is getting lost on the displaced, unemployed American workforce so pro Trump. Foreign policy affects domestic economy in a global market. If we do not have the respect of Mexico, of Britain, of China we will be shooting ourselves in the foot before we even make the artful deal Trump keeps spinning.  Trump talks of leverage. A Trump presidency would take so much leverage away from our "deal makers" before the dialogue even begins. Consequently, job opportunity could get lost inside our borders.

Any Republican running MUST get the support of at least 80 percent of Republicans and a coalition of moderate democrats and a large majority of independents. I personally would be shocked if this man can get those numbers. What he has now is about 30-35 percent (mostly republicans or crossover democrats who were permitted to vote in those states that allow it) of people in this country who feel disaffected, disillusioned, angry about some real things (political correctness comes to mind). This issue irritates me as well but I would not vote for someone who breaks all the rules of common decency. He only has to open his mouth to reveal his ignorance of even the basic issues that are facing this country. His answers are mostly platitudes. Nothing more. I am surprised that anyone over the age of 12 thinks he is qualified to be President.

Trump does not have to be interpreted. He can be read as easy as a primer reader.

Which presidential candidate is a person with a sadistic personality demonstrating a pervasive pattern of cruel, demeaning, and aggressive behavior?

Which presidential candidate gains satisfaction from intimidating, coercing, hurting, and humiliating others?

Which presidential candidate is frightening and cruel, and appears to relish the acts of menacing and brutalizing others, and forcing others to cower and submit, gaining satisfaction from bullying others?

Do you want this kind of person to be a role model for your children and grandchildren?

Do you want the President of the United States to behave in these ways?

By the way, people who behaved this way and behave this way were and are slave drivers, and also those who chased down and chase down runaway slaves.

replies.commentBody: The last two GOP businessmen who became president: Herbert Hoover and George W. Bush.

comments.commentBody:
NYT and the majority of its readers are scared to death that someone who has a track record of real [business] accomplishments - instead of hot air and feel good politics - might be elected President. I have no vested interest in Donald Trump, but the real and dismaying awakening is seeing the fear and loathing among those who think they are superior - by education, location of residence, and other phony criteria - to other Americans.
You anti-Trump-ers are just as bad, biased and extreme as the "right wingnuts" you decry. Just the opposite side. Look in the mirror!

I agree with the comparison mentioned between Donald Trump and Italy’s perennial peri-millennial Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi.  I find it far more apt - if far less sensational - than the comparison with Mussolini.  Were it not for the ten year age discrepancy between the two, they could have been twins separated at birth.  Both are wealthy, vulgar celebrities with media savvy and bad hair. The major problem of course is that Trump aspires to make or keep (depending on your views) the USA the dominant world power, and even Berlusconi had no such ambitions for Italy.

I can't say it any better than the Guardian newspaper---"What Lewandowski and Nussbaum are saying, then, should be obvious to anyone who’s dipped a toe outside the prosperous enclaves on the two coasts. Ill-considered trade deals and generous bank bailouts and guaranteed profits for insurance companies but no recovery for average people, ever – these policies have taken their toll. As Trump says, “we have rebuilt China and yet our country is falling apart. Our infrastructure is falling apart … Our airports are, like, Third World.”

Trump’s words articulate the populist backlash against liberalism that has been building slowly for decades and may very well occupy the White House itself, whereupon the entire world will be required to take seriously its demented ideas.

Yet still we cannot bring ourselves to look the thing in the eyes. We cannot admit that we liberals bear some of the blame for its emergence, for the frustration of the working-class millions, for their blighted cities and their downward spiraling lives. So much easier to scold them for their twisted racist souls, to close our eyes to the obvious reality of which Trumpism is just a crude and ugly expression: that neoliberalism has well and truly failed."

What if the real reason Trump keeps ob going like the energizer bunny  is because he wants to sell his stuff- hotels, steaks, etc.? He's just another American capitalist. Having the presidency can make him  richer than Rockerfeller or even the Clintons.

What if the real reason Trump keeps of going like the energizer bunny  is because he wants to sell his stuff- hotels, steaks, etc.? He's just another American capitalist. Having the presidency can make him  richer than Rockerfeller or even the Clintons.

replies.commentBody:
Sam asks a good question.

I would be shocked to hear that the foreign media have reported to Sam just how upset the American people are with our vandal destroyer of a president. He has trashed so much of what is wonderful and good about the USA that ANY strong individual who speaks of independence will gain much support.

Obama always thought of himself as the redistribution president of the world, but very FEW Americans have any sort of positive opinion of redistribution because it burns away half of what is forced out of the individual's hands to give to a client of the state.
It baffles me, too, and I'm from this country.
There's plenty of right and wrong, and could we PLEASE stop cheerleading for civil war?

comments.commentBody: As a foreign, I am curious about the comments here. Trump is winning many states and heading to a potential republic nominee position. No matter what he did or said, the result was decided by the voters in all those states. Does this result, at least the current one, represents some voters' opinions about what the US president should be? The NYT readers definitely represents a group of people, according to my limited observation, most Democratic. And their opinions about the future president is apparently different from the people who voted for Trump. Isn't this an example showing how divided the country is? Which group of people is right? Or there is no right or wrong?

replies.commentBody: Robert plays the bully as well as non-drinker, non-smoker Trump ever could.

comments.commentBody:
I don't understand what's so hard to understand about Donald Trump.

This is a guy who was born rich, and who made more money tearing neighborhoods into bits and sellong the bits. He has almost exactly the attitudes--and contempt for working people--of everybody else in that crowd.

And, he's got a serious need to have people cheer him. So, and after a number of false starts, he's grabbed onto a moment in American history when a lot of white guys (many of whom are fairly ignorant) are scared about their jobs, and the way the country and the world is changing.

Shockingly, he's succeeded through a combo of grabbing onto a real issue--jobs and trade--and pandering to pretty much the ugliest ideas there are in this country.

Shockingly, too, he's been pumped up by a media that's become interested in ad dollars first and last.

Shockingly, he hasn't been stopped by a GOP that's done nothing but scream, yell, refuse, chop rich people's taxes and get us into stupid wars.

Why is this difficult to see? Is it because too many are afraid to call this guy the loudmouthed bully and racist that he is? Are we scared of saying that wealthy people don't care, unless they want something? Of being creeped out by his weird attitudes towards women?

It's simple. A loudmouthed bully has found his moment.

The true tragedy is that I have extended a friendly hand and wanted to help the people over the last quarter of century but haven’t found a single individual needing any assistance.

Everybody believes they understand the problems perfectly well, but for some unknown reason they cannot fix them.

The truth is if you cannot fix the problems you don’t understand them...

replies.commentBody: I think Mr. Donne was wrong.  Trump's eventual death is not going to diminish anybody.

comments.commentBody:
No man is an island,
Entire of itself,
Every man is a piece of the continent,
A part of the main.
If a clod be washed away by the sea,
Europe is the less.
As well as if a promontory were.
As well as if a manor of thy friend's
Or of thine own were:
Any man's death diminishes me,
Because I am involved in mankind,
And therefore never send to know for whom the bell tolls;
It tolls for thee.

— John Donne

replies.commentBody: Kenan-- "extraordinary leaders"?!  Trump has shown no true leadership qualities whatsoever.  The only thing he can do is stir anger in people so that it creates hatred, bigotry and desperation.

You're honestly arguing that Dinald Trump demonstrates courage, dignity, character and intellect?

Good grief.

comments.commentBody:
Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders are two extraordinary leaders in completely different league in comparison to their rivals that more look like the phony parrots endlessly repeating the old partisan mantra.

Both Trump and Sanders crossed Rubicon and partially blamed their own parties for the colossal problems.

The prerequisite for such a gigantic breakthrough is personal courage, dignity, character and intellect.

Finding the best solutions to the current problems is a matter of time after they displayed their willingness to accept the personal responsibility for the current crisis.

March 9, 2016
The populace right is wallowing in its vulgar hurrah, eagerly licking its chops for the General Election take over – More the anti-progressives in feral anticipation to abolish the Obama achievements. Does American politics have to be this bad and immature of refinement – no. But does so because there’s a mis-translation of the recent historic times; resulting in defective 'reality' politics for domestic and international agendas. Yet the more we critique the mood and the angst the more the Democratic party is holding its courage and remains the can do solidarity party for family values, with expectant leading in: honor, virtue, and grace: well serving its likely Hillary Clinton commanding achievements to take to the oval office.

jja Manhattan, N.Y.C. ( Independent voter - registered Republican

Is Trump different from Netanyahu, our "democratic" ally?

Netanyahu leads Israel, claims he speaks for all Jews, effects people's perceptions of Israel, and, because of Netanyahu's claims, people's perceptions of Jews. President Trump will effect people's perceptions of the U.S. and Americans. Will people misperceive the U.S. and Americans because of President Trump? Do people misperceive Israel and Jews because of Netanyahu?

Why is there a Republican stop Trump movement? Who is behind it? What are their fears? First, Trump will destroy the G.O,P., their power. Second, maybe, that Trump will destroy the U.S.

Who's part of "stop Trump" in the GOP? I'll bet most of 30% of American Jews who are Republicans. The Jews who fund and dominate AIPAC. Wealthy Jews whose patronage is courted. People who shilled to get Netanyahu before Congress to denounce the Iran nuclear deal. But why are they fighting Trump?

Trump would build a wall. Netanyahu built a wall. Trump wants to bar all Muslims. Netanyahu squeezes out Muslims. Trump wants to kill terrorists families. Netanyahu levels Gaza.

Republican Jews, rich or poor, understand why Trump is bad for Republicans, for the U.S., for Americans. But Netanyahu and Likud? No! It must be anti-Semitism! No other explanation possible! And West Bank settler demonstrations look nothing, nothing at all, like Trump rallies!

You understand the impact of Trump. You cannot deny the impact of Netanyahu.

"Stop Trump" is a double standard, no?

The media focuses so much on Trump's comments and not nearly enough on actions.  If actions were cared about more than words (and they should be), then we'd have 10x more articles on Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio than Donald Trump.  Donald Trump has no political history (in the sense that he hasn't been a senator/congressman/etc).  However, Ted Cruz has a concrete history of actions that have been fanatical and terrible (remember the government shutdown anyone?).  Marco Rubio's actions?  Well, more lack of, since he doesn't show up for work.  If I had to, I'd roll the dice and vote for Trump over Cruz/Rubio any day.  Though I certainly won't be voting for any of the 3, I'll take any democrat available, any at all.

I wonder if the GOP will stop "rigging" the primary votes in the future!
We have a saying: do not dig a hole, or do not dig it too deep, cause you never know who will fall in it.

They rigged Florida to be winner take all and now ouch, HE will take it all next Tuesday.

The way to take on Trump is not by calling him a hate monger or exposing some scam he was involved in.  The way to take on Trump is to acknowledge that anybody who can carry Mississippi and Massachusetts must be on to something.       Bernie is the extreme, utterly unrealistic personification of this, but everyone else is selling old wine in new bottles.

In rural Burgundy, the local, blue-collar population -- farmers, bakers, mechanics, almost exclusively white -- the very group that is embracing Mr. Trump at home in the US-- is as baffled as many American observers are by Mr. Trump. I recently discussed the American political landscape with 60 of them and I was surprised by the depth of their concern about Mr. Trump. It wasn't vague anxiety; it was specific fear about his chest-thumping xenophobia and his apparent total lack of a foreign policy vision for the world's most powerful country. On the one hand, it was remarkable that this group was paying such close attention to elections an ocean away. On the other hand, it was disconcerting to find myself having to defend the very system that makes candidates like Mr. Trump possible.

Even far from the land of the Stars and Stripes, the Republican front runner is forcing people to talk about him. No matter what they are saying, he must be elated.
